presentation.title: Subsistence fishing in MG
presentation.runninghead: Values of fish to coastal populations in Madagascar

page.name: Subsistence fishing
page.title: Introduction
page.description:
This storyline demonstrates the use of ARIES in quantifying specific values of an ecosystem service. In this case we concentrate on the value of fish resources to coastal population that depend on fish for sustainance.

Subsistence harvesting of ecosystem goods is critical in the developing world as well as in developed nations. Such ecosystem goods have been termed the “GDP of the poor”, since they provide employment and livelihoods for many of the world’s poor while not being monetized in traditional economic accounts like GDP. Societal dependence on subsistence fisheries, combined with overfishing, pollution, and climate change, demands sustainable management of aquatic resources.

Thanks to the support of the UNEP World Conservation Monitoring Centre we have developed this storyline for Madagascar, chosen because of its high rate of poverty, dependence on fisheries as a key protein source in rural communities, and prevalent deforestation-driven sedimentation and erosion, which strongly affect its coastal and marine systems.
page.see-also: The fisheries section of the ARIES web site
page.credits: Funding: UNEP World Conservation Monitoring Centre.

page.name: Proximity
page.title: Distance To Coast
page.description: Populations that live in the coastal area in poor countries depend on fish stocks for their daily subsistence. This analysis was therefore restricted to populations living close to the coast. In this storyline, we used a coastal buffer of 5km, assuming that the likely beneficiaries of subsistence fisheries need to be able to reach the coast walking or biking. Distance to the coast was categorized in three classes of distance, and this variable entered the probabilistic calculation of the benefitshed.
page.see-also: The fisheries section of the ARIES web site
page.credits:
Data provided by: public world coastline database
Funding: UNEP World Conservation Monitoring Centre.

page.name: Population
page.title: Population Density
page.description: In order to determine the need for subsistence fisheries, population density data were used as a first step to determine the initial multiplier for the amount of need. The data were intersected them with the chosen coastal distance layer to start determininig how many people are likely to need subsistence fishing in the area. This map shows population for all of Madagascar, and is used as an input in the probabilistic benefitshed calculations.
page.see-also: The fisheries section of the ARIES web site
page.credits:
Data provided by: LANDSCAN, Oak Ridge National Laboratories
Funding: UNEP World Conservation Monitoring Centre.

page.name: Poverty
page.title: Poverty level
page.description: People are more likely to access fisheries for subsistence purposes when they lack other sources of nutrition. Poverty rates estimated by Elvidge et al. (2009) were used as part of the probabilistic determination of the degree of subsistence fisheries use. The map shows reclassified poverty rates for the whole region of interest.
page.see-also:
Elvidge, C.D., P.S. Sutton, K.E. Baugh, B.T. Tuttle, A.T. Howard, E.H. Erwin, B. Bhaduri, and E. Bright. 2009. A global poverty map derived from satellite data. Computers and Geosciences 35 (8): 1652-1660.
The fisheries section of the ARIES web site
page.credits:
Data provided by: Elvidge et al., 2009
Funding: UNEP World Conservation Monitoring Centre.

page.name: Subsistence Use
page.title: Subsistence Use
page.description:
Benefitshed map

This map depicts our benefitshed, the result of the probabilistic modelling of the need for fish to support the livelihoods of coastal populations. Darker blues indicate a need that is higher in poorer populations that live closer to the coast. The map you are seeing is a probabilistic one, illustrating the probability of needing fish for subsistence. You can click on the map and visualize the probability distribution in each point. The flow model you will see later determines the actual value of the fish resource, depending on the need, the quality and abundance of the resource, and the ability of accessing it by walking to the shoreline.
page.see-also: The fisheries section of the ARIES web site
page.credits: Funding: UNEP World Conservation Monitoring Centre.

page.name: Sky emperor
page.title: Sky emperor abundance
page.description:
Now that we have quantified the need for fish, we must model the likely provision of fish. Data about abundance of different species of fish are hard to find, but some are available from The Sea Around Us project and can be used as a starting point in modeling the likely availability. We have chosen the three most important species for subsistence in Madagascar. What you are looking at here is the relative abundance of Lethrinus mahsena (sky emperor). The numbers here have relative significance, as the actual harvest data are shown later by intersecting with catch data from FAO.

The data have 0.5 degree resolution, so we must use a coarse grid. Yet, ARIES can automatically interpolate with the result of other models to provide better looking maps, and will compute the uncertainty related to the interpolation so that no information gets lost.
page.see-also:
Lethrinus mahsena on FishBase
The fisheries section of the ARIES web site
page.credits:
Data provided by: Sea Around Us project
Funding: UNEP World Conservation Monitoring Centre.

page.name: Snubnose emperor
page.title: Snubnose emperor abundance
page.description:
Data about abundance of different species of fish are hard to find, but some are available from The Sea Around Us project and can be used as a starting point in modeling the likely availability. What you are looking at here is the relative abundance of Lethrinus borbonicus (snubnose emperor). The numbers here have relative significance, as the actual harvest data are shown later by intersecting with catch data from FAO.

The data have 0.5 degree resolution, so we must use a coarse grid. Yet, ARIES can automatically interpolate with the result of other models to provide better looking maps, and will compute the uncertainty related to the interpolation so that no information gets lost.

page.name: Mangrove snapper
page.title: Mangrove red snapper abundance
page.description:
Data about abundance of different species of fish are hard to find, but some are available from The Sea Around Us project and can be used as a starting point in modeling the likely availability. What you are looking at here is the relative abundance of Lutjanus argentimaculatus (mangrove red snapper). The numbers here have relative significance, as the actual harvest data are shown later by intersecting with catch data from FAO.

The data have 0.5 degree resolution, so we must use a coarse grid. Yet, ARIES can automatically interpolate with the result of other models to provide better looking maps, and will compute the uncertainty related to the interpolation so that no information gets lost.

page.name: Total harvest
page.title: Total potential subsistence harvest
page.description:
Provisionshed map

The source of benefits for this storyline is the total amount of potential fish harvestable by coastal populations. Only a small fraction of this potential is usable by the beneficiaries; the computation of the actually used potential is shown later in the flow model output.

Historical catch data are published by the FAO (2008). These data do not explicitly describe subsistence catch and do not contain catch records specific to any of the species for which we have relative abundance data. Despite these limitations, we can use assumptions to estimate the likely supply or source value for each species. These assumptions can be adjusted should more refined fisheries information become available. This map shows estimated source values for the mangrove red snapper (Lutjanus argentimaculatus). A similar process was used to estimate source values for the other species considered. The sum of these maps constitutes our source model.

Historical catch data from The Sea Around Us Project shows that 71.6% of the total catch for Madagascar from 1950-2004 is “non-identified marine pelagic fishes.” In 2005, Madagascar produced 138,477 tonnes of fish from capture fisheries, of which 77,636 tonnes were for commodity trade and production. Another 72,300 tonnes were taken by traditional fishermen; however, this catch is not necessarily mutually exclusive of the commodity sector. Subtracting the commodity catch from the total catch leaves 60,841 tonnes of fish which we assume goes toward local consumption. Assuming 71.6% of the locally consumed fish are “non-identified marine pelagic fishes,” these account for 43,562 tonnes. Assuming that each of the fish species for which we have distribution data accounted for 20% of that total, this would give 8,712 tonnes of fish caught for each of these species. We then divide the total catch for each species according to their relative abundance along the Madagascar coast in order to produce a map of subsistence fish production for each species under the above assumptions (Equation 1). A similar equation holds for subsistence fisheries use (Equation 2).

(1) S = a1S1 + a2S2 + a3S3 + … + anSn
(2) D = a1S1 + a2S2 + a3S3 + … + anSn

Where

S
the total source or supply of subsistence fisheries (kg)
D
the total demand for subsistence fisheries (kg)
an
the percentage of the total demand met with species n
Sn
the total mass of species n caught (kg)

We make a series of simplifying assumptions based on limited data regarding the magnitude of supply and demand in Madagascar’s subsistence fishery and the distribution of valuable species. Given better data and/or expert knowledge of the relative use of different species, ARIES can adjust the model coefficients to more accurately quantify human dependence on Madagascar’s fisheries.
page.see-also:
FAO fishery statistical collections
The fisheries section of the ARIES web site
page.credits:
Data provided by: FAO 2008
Funding: UNEP World Conservation Monitoring Centre.

page.name: Paths
page.title: Pathways to shore
page.description:
We have computed both the amount of need (benefitshed) and the amount of potential provision (provisionshed) of fish. The last step of the analysis is modelling the flow of this ecosystem service to the beneficiaries we have identified, which allows us to understand the actual value of this resource in this context, as well as pointing out areas of unmet need and inefficiencies in the use of the resource.

The subsistence fisheries flow model shows the expected spatial dependence of specific fisheries users on particular fisheries areas. Users are assumed to move from a point of origin (their homes) to an oceanic fishery, harvest fish, and return to their homes, where fish are consumed, via road or path networks.

This map shows the paths and road network that determines the accessibility of the locations where fish are provided. The flow model moves a given quantity of fish (in kg) from the ocean to areas of demand along these roads or paths. Each coastal ocean point has an estimated potential source of fish, computed as our provisionshed model. Each point on land has an estimated potential use for oceanic fish, computed in our benefitshed model.

We assume that the use of oceanic subsistence fisheries is greatest close to the coast and declines relatively quickly moving inland. We model this distance decay as a Gaussian curve with high subsistence use within 1 km of the coast, steep decline at distances of 2-3 km of the coast, and slowly declining subsistence use out to a distance of 5 km of the coast.
page.see-also: The fisheries section of the ARIES web site
page.credits:
Data provided by: Madagascar infrastructure database (BD500)
Funding: UNEP World Conservation Monitoring Centre.

page.name: Actual value
page.title: Actually utilized subsistence fish
page.description: The quantity of fish harvested for subsistence use.
page.see-also: The fisheries section of the ARIES web site

page.name: Satisfied need
page.title: Satisfied subsistence fish demand
page.description: The portion of demand for fish satisfied by flows of fish to people from a fishery area.
page.see-also: The fisheries section of the ARIES web site

page.name: Unused fish
page.title: Unutilized subsistence fish
page.description: Fisheries that are not used due to lack of proximity or pathways to users. This value may also be positive if some of the fish supply remains after all demand is satiatied.
page.see-also: The fisheries section of the ARIES web site

page.name: Unmet need
page.title: Unsatisfied subsistence fish demand
page.description: The portion of demand for fish not satisfied due to inadequate size of the fishery or a lack of proximity to a fishery. If this is zero, some unutilized fish may be a result of a true surplus and not just a lack of proximity. If this is greater than zero, there is no surplus within range.
page.see-also: The fisheries section of the ARIES web site
